summary: This document is an email chain forwarding Ghislaine Maxwell's Federal Rule of Evidence 412 motion to the court. It shows communication between defense attorneys and the judge's chambers regarding the submission of a motion to exclude certain evidence, with deadlines and hearing dates mentioned.

persons.name: Nicole Simmons
persons.context: Sends the defense motion to Judge Nathan's chambers on behalf of Jeffrey Pagliuca.

persons.name: Nathan
persons.context: Presiding judge in the case U.S. v. Maxwell, to whom the motion is addressed.

persons.name: Jeffrey Pagliuca
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell who requested the motion be submitted.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Copied on the email submitting the motion, indicating involvement in the defense.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Subject of the criminal case and the defendant whose motion is being filed.

connections.description: Pagliuca is filing a motion on behalf of Maxwell as her defense attorney.
Menninger is copied on the motion submission, indicating she is part of Maxwell's defense team.
Simmons sends the motion at Pagliuca's request, suggesting a working relationship.
Nathan is the presiding judge over Maxwell's criminal case.

events.title: Submission of Rule 412 Motion
events.description: Defense files a motion under Federal Rule of Evidence 412 in the Ghislaine Maxwell case.

events.title: Tentative Hearing Date
events.description: A hearing on the Rule 412 motion is tentatively scheduled.

locations: Haddon, Morgan and Foreman P.C. (law firm)
keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team filed a Federal Rule of Evidence 412 motion, which typically concerns the admissibility of evidence related to a victim's sexual behavior or predisposition.
The motion was submitted by attorney Jeffrey Pagliuca via paralegal Nicole Simmons to Judge Alison J. Nathan's chambers.
The prosecution's response to the motion was due by Monday following October 28, 2021, with a tentative hearing set for November 5, 2021.
The document is part of the case U.S. v. Maxwell, Case No. 20 Cr. 330 (AJN), indicating ongoing pre-trial litigation.
The email chain shows formal communication protocols between defense counsel and the federal court in a high-profile case.
